subject: Home & DIY
title: Reclaimed Wood's Second Life
description: A quick, practical guide to Reclaimed Wood's Second Life.

hook.text: A barn beam from the 1800s is often stronger than new lumber. Old-growth wood was denser and tighter-grained.

buildup.text: Reclaimed wood comes from old buildings, barns, railroad ties, and even sunken river logs pulled up after 100+ years.

discovery.text: Old-growth timber had centuries to grow slowly. Modern plantation trees grow fast but produce softer, weaker wood.

twist.text: Reclaimed wood costs 2-3x more than new lumber. The premium covers deconstruction, denailing, resizing, and kiln drying.

climax.text: Each reclaimed board saves a tree and diverts construction waste from landfills. Its embodied carbon is already spent.

punchline.text: The best wood for your home was felled 150 years ago.

quiz.question: Why is old-growth reclaimed wood often stronger than new lumber?
options: Slow growth over centuries produced denser, tighter-grained wood
Aging chemically hardens the wood fibers over time
Old-growth trees were a genetically superior species
